pageData.text: Most plants undergo <button class='glossary-text'>sexual reproduction</button> as part of their life cycle. <button class='glossary-text'>Pollination</button> refers to the delivery of the <button class='glossary-text'>pollen grain</button> to the part of the <button class='glossary-text'>flower</button> containing the egg. Pollination mechanisms are important in plant propagation, adaptation, and evolution. The anatomy of several different flowers will be examined, and plant reproduction, flower anatomy, and pollination will be discussed.

Determine flower types.

pageData.text: Most of the food crops that we grow are dependent on pollinators to reproduce, particularly bees. Since most plants have evolved to be pollinated by a single type of organism, this leaves our food supply particularly vulnerable to anything that affects these pollinators. Unfortunately, many factors are currently threatening our bee populations which, if not dealt with, could affect our ability to produce enough food. One threat to bee health is a lack of biodiversity in plant species, particularly in agricultural areas. This is because most food is grown on industrial farms that grow one crop at a time, a technique called monoculture. These farms may also use insecticides that inadvertently harm helpful bees. Other threats to bees include invasive species like wasps, parasites, and other pathogens, as well as rising temperatures and increasingly extreme weather caused by climate change.

Areas of industrial agriculture can be made more habitable for bees by adding buffer zones of pollinator-friendly plants around and between sections of crop land, and limiting or eliminating the use of pesticides harmful to bees. Individuals can do their part by planting in their gardens <button class='glossary-text'>flowers</button> that provide food sources for bees and stopovers for migrating pollinators like butterflies.

pageData.altText: Bees pollinating lavender plants.

pageData.text: Plants can reproduce by two general means. <button class='glossary-text'>Asexual reproduction</button> occurs without recombination of genetic material. The most familiar type of asexual reproduction in plants is <button class='glossary-text'>vegetative reproduction</button>. Certain parts of the plant retain the ability to produce unspecialized tissue capable of regenerating all the tissues necessary to form a new, intact, and complete plant. In this regard, plants differ from most animals. An example of vegetative reproduction is the plant Kalanchoe beharensis. Leaves of this plant can produce numerous small rootlike structures called rootlets. When the leaf is shed from the “mother” plant, the rootlets will grow into the soil and develop into a new “daughter” plant. Another example is the production of buds in unusual places, sometimes in response to a wound. These are called adventitious buds. In some plants, they develop on roots and mature into <button class='glossary-text'>rhizomes</button>. Since the rhizome is a stem, it has nodes from which roots and shoots can grow and develop into a new plant some distance from the original. Once the new plant is established and capable of photosynthesizing, it is independent and the rhizome can be severed. Vegetative reproduction enhances the continued success of a species in an environment from one year to the next and can be a sign of stress in harsh environmental conditions. Vegetative reproduction is used to propagate a particular plant line that has desirable characteristics.

The second method of plant reproduction is <button class='glossary-text'>sexual reproduction</button>. Plant cells contain two full sets of DNA, the genetic material. Sexual reproduction requires a special kind of cell division called <button class='glossary-text'>meiosis</button> that produces cells with just one (complete) set of DNA, <button class='glossary-text'>haploid</button> cells, called <button class='glossary-text'>gametes</button>. As part of sexual reproduction, male and female gametes, sperm and eggs, respectively, will change to produce a <button class='glossary-text'>zygote</button>, which will develop into an <button class='glossary-text'>embryo</button>. The embryo has a normal, double set of DNA. The embryo of higher plants is contained within a <button class='glossary-text'>seed</button>, which protects, and in some cases nourishes, the embryo.

In plants, the sexual life cycle is more complicated than that of animals (Figure 1). Most plants have a dominant sporophyte generation, which is the main plant structure we see when we look at a tree or flowering plant. The sporophyte generation is diploid and produces <button class='glossary-text'>haploid</button> spores by <button class='glossary-text'>meiosis</button>. The spores give rise to either male or female gametophyte generations, which are often housed within structures of the larger sporophyte generation. These gametophytes are haploid and produce haploid male or female <button class='glossary-text'>gametes</button>. When these gametes combine in fertilization the resulting offspring develops into the next sporophyte generation.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Plant life cycle. Alternation of generations between a diploid sporophyte and a haploid gametophyte.

pageData.text: Many of the larger plants in our everyday world are either gymnosperms or angiosperms. These are the only two plant groups that produce <button class='glossary-text'>seeds</button>. The <button class='glossary-text'>gametes</button> of angiosperms develop will change to produce a <button class='glossary-text'>zygote</button>, which will develop into an <button class='glossary-text'>embryo</button>. In the <button class='glossary-text'>flower</button>, a specialized structure for <button class='glossary-text'>sexual reproduction</button>. A diagram of a typical flower can be seen in Figure 2. Plants are different from most animals in that one plant can give rise to both male and female gametophytes to produce egg and sperm. In some cases, this results in <button class='glossary-text'>self-fertilization</button>, which means that two gametes from one plant can fuse. In most plants, however, two gametes from different plants combine, and the new individual is genetically distinct from either parent. The flower shown in Figure 2 is an example of a “perfect” flower, that is, it can produce both male and female gametes. This is not true for all flowers but is common. Perfect flowers have the potential for self-fertilization.

In the center of the flower is the <button class='glossary-text'>pistil</button>, the part of the flower that produces eggs and protects the developing seed. While this part of the flower is often called “female,” the term is not strictly accurate. The <button class='glossary-text'>ovary</button> is the enlarged, lower part of the pistil, visible in Figure 2, and it contains the <button class='glossary-text'>ovules</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Meiosis</button> and egg production occur within the small ovules. The entire ovule will develop into the seed and the fertilized egg will develop into the <button class='glossary-text'>embryo</button>. At the same time, while the seeds are maturing, the ovary matures into a <button class='glossary-text'>fruit</button>. Botanically speaking, many structures commonly called vegetables—such as tomatoes, beans, and cucumbers—are fruits.

The <button class='glossary-text'>stamens</button> are arranged around the pistil. Most flowers have one pistil and numerous stamens. Stamens have a long <button class='glossary-text'>filament</button> that supports the <button class='glossary-text'>anthers</button>. The anthers are composed of chambers where meiosis occurs. This is where the <button class='glossary-text'>pollen grain</button> (male gametophyte) develops, which produces the male gametes or sperm.

You can see in Figure 2 that the pistil contains a tubelike structure, the <button class='glossary-text'>style</button>, with a flat, broad structure on its upper surface called the <button class='glossary-text'>stigma</button>.

The stigma will receive the <button class='glossary-text'>pollen grains</button>, which produce a <button class='glossary-text'>pollen tube</button> that grows down the style into the ovary. The sperm travels through this tube into the ovules where they fuse with the eggs.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Labeled diagram of the parts of a flower.

pageData.question: What part of the flower will develop into a seed after fertilization?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The entire ovule will develop into a seed, and the fertilized egg will develop into an embryo.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Gymnosperms and angiosperms are the only two plant groups that produce seeds.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The gametes of angiosperms develop in the flower, a specialized structure for sexual reproduction. In the center of the flower is the pistil, the part of the flower that produces eggs and protects the developing seed. While this part of the flower is often called “female,” the term is not strictly accurate. The ovary is the enlarged, lower part pistil, and it contains the ovule. Meiosis and egg production occur within the small ovules. The entire ovule will develop into a seed, and the fertilized egg will develop into an embryo.The stamens are arranged around the pistil. Most flowers have one pistil and numerous stamens. Stamens have a long filament that supports the anthers. The anthers are composed of chambers where meiosis occurs. The pistil contains a tube-like structure, the style, with a flat, broad structure on its upper surface called the stigma. The stigma will receive the pollen grains, which produce a pollen tube that grows down the style into the ovary. The sperm travels through this tube into the ovules where they fuse with the eggs.

hintData.body: The gametes of angiosperms develop in the flower, a specialized structure for sexual reproduction. In the center of the flower is the pistil, the part of the flower that produces eggs and protects the developing seed. While this part of the flower is often called “female,” the term is not strictly accurate. The ovary is the enlarged, lower part pistil, and it contains the ovule. Meiosis and egg production occur within the small ovules. The entire ovule will develop into a seed, and the fertilized egg will develop into an embryo.The stamens are arranged around the pistil. Most flowers have one pistil and numerous stamens. Stamens have a long filament that supports the anthers. The anthers are composed of chambers where meiosis occurs. The pistil contains a tube-like structure, the style, with a flat, broad structure on its upper surface called the stigma. The stigma will receive the pollen grains, which produce a pollen tube that grows down the style into the ovary. The sperm travels through this tube into the ovules where they fuse with the eggs.

img.alt: Figure 2: Labeled diagram of the parts of a flower.

pageData.text: The and are surrounded by , collectively called the corolla, usually arranged in a whorl. Beneath the petals, also usually arranged in a whorl, are small, usually green, leaflike structures called the . Collectively, the sepals are called the , which is Latin for cup, because it resembles a cup holding the . The entire flower structure is located on a specialized branch called the , and the flower sits on the of the peduncle. Figure 2

Some flowers may be associated with leaflike bracts. These are not actually part of the flower. In some cases, such as the common field flower Dogwood (Figure 3), the bracts can be large and bright white while the petals are small and inconspicuous.

Delivery of the pollen grain to the <button class='glossary-text'>stigma</button> is called <button class='glossary-text'>pollination</button>. Pollination can occur by many different mechanisms, and the structure of the stamens and pistils may be modified in ways that accommodate their particular method of pollination.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Dogwood flowers illustrating bracts, which superficially resemble flower petals.

pageData.text: <button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button> shows some of the <button class='glossary-text'>flower</button> traits and how they are related to pollinators. There are a wide variety of colors, odors, shapes, and nectars in flowers to attract the “correct” pollinator.

The flower and its type of <button class='glossary-text'>pollination</button> are finely tuned and specific. A plant’s flowering may be timed to coincide with the availability of its insect or bird pollinator. Other plants modify the flower structure to accommodate the pollinator. For example, some flowers have long narrow <button class='glossary-text'>petals</button> that are a good fit for the elongated beak of a hummingbird. These specific pollination mechanisms confer certain advantages. They increase the probability that the pollen will be delivered to the correct flower, and the plant may not need to produce as much pollen as a species without these specific mechanisms. Wind-pollinated plants, for example, produce a large amount of pollen, and much of it is delivered to the “wrong” plant, if it is delivered to a plant at all. Nonspecific delivery of pollen, though wasteful, is not in itself a problem. Different species of plants are not genetically compatible. This incompatibility normally prevents pollination and fertilization.

Insect and bird pollinators can be attracted to the flowers by odor, color, or both. A pollinator that is attracted by nectar will enter the flower to get to the nectar and carry some of the pollen away when it exits. When the pollinator visits another flower, it will pick up new pollen and leave some of the old pollen on the newly visited flower. If genetically compatible, pollination and fertilization may result. As discussed earlier, many flowers produce both male and female <button class='glossary-text'>gametes</button>. These plants would be capable of self-pollination, depositing the pollen from the flower on the <button class='glossary-text'>stigma</button> of the same flower, which could then result in <button class='glossary-text'>self-fertilization</button>. Although this does occur, self-fertilization is believed to circumvent one of the major functions of <button class='glossary-text'>sexual reproduction</button>: to enhance genetic recombination and permit adaptation and evolution. Plants have developed a variety of different mechanisms to limit self-pollination. One mechanism is to make the stigma receptive to pollen at a different time from when the pollen is shed. Other plants have developed self-incompatibility mechanisms, in which a pollen protein is recognized as “self,” and pollination is prevented.

Large funnel shaped with strong foundation

pageData.question: Elongated, funnel-shaped flowers are most likely adapted to attract which of the following pollinators?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Flowers that are shaped like a large funnel are adapted for pollination by birds.

pageData.question: A flower that blooms only at night is most likely adapted to attract which of the following pollinators?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Flowers that only bloom at night are adapted for pollination by bats.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Remove and dry the specimen, then examine its exterior. Then, examine the number, position, and size of the petals. Next, spread open the specimen, and count the stamen number and measure the stamen length. Then, count the pistil number and measure the pistil length. Next, remove and examine the stamen. Then, examine the style and measure the style length. Then, examine the stigma. If the specimen has the largest ovary, isolate the ovary and cut it in half lengthwise. This activity is repeated for the four flower specimens in the investigation.

Due to supply shortages, the cucumber is replacing one of the original flowers from this investigation. Please verify that the flowers in your kit match the flowers in this materials section. If you have different flowers than the manual, refer to your instructor for access to the correct lab manual.
This investigation requires safety goggles, disposable gloves, and a lab apron.

pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Follow the instructions for this activity closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE); goggles, gloves, and lab aprons must be worn when dissecting. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing the dissection. Use proper hygiene practices before, during, and after the lab, including washing your hands before and after performing the dissection. Review pertinent portions of any Safety Data Sheets (SDS) before beginning the activity. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) is flammable. Keep away from open flame if using alcohol as a disinfectant.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

pageData.text: Dissections require special attention to safety. Please follow these additional precautions:

text: Clean the counter or work space thoroughly before and after the dissection. If the isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant) is insufficient for removing grease during cleanup, you may use soap and water, followed by more alcohol/disinfectant.
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the dissection.
Only perform the dissection on the dissecting tray. This will contain both the specimen and any excess fluids.
Spread the absorbent pad blue-side down underneath the tray to capture any spilled fluid.
In general, scissors are used more frequently than the scalpel, especially when care must be taken not to cut too deeply into the specimen.

pageData.text: • Scalpels are used infrequently in most dissection labs and require special handling and disposal:

• Never cut toward your holding hand and fingers.
    • Cut in a downward motion using a steady, even pressure.
    • Always use a sharp blade.
    • Do not use a scalpel that is nicked, bent, or damaged.
    • Do not use a scalpel to cut through bone or heavy cartilage.
    • Never use a scalpel for anything other than dissection.

pageData.subTitle: Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup className=bodySupscript>®</sup>
pageData.text: Independent, certified laboratory analyses of specimens fixed in Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup className=bodySupscript>®</sup> have found that it is nontoxic and does not give off dangerous fumes. This means that, for safety purposes, use of Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup className=bodySupscript>®</sup> specimens does not require specialized ventilation. Carolina does recommend performing the dissection in a well-ventilated room with some active ventilation when working with any preserved specimens. For a home setting, this may include opening windows and turning on a ceiling fan. The safe nature of Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup className=bodySupscript>®</sup> also means that in most localities there are no mandated disposal requirements.

Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup className=bodySupscript>®</sup> causes mild <button class='glossary-text'>skin</button> irritation if suitable PPE is not worn. Avoid contact with skin and <button class='glossary-text'>eyes</button>. Do not ingest specimen, especially if you are or may become pregnant.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.text: Carolina’s Carosafe®Carosafe® is a preservative and holding solution for biological specimens. It contains no formaldehyde and is not a tissue fixative. Most specimens in Carosafe® are first preserved with a formalin solution and then washed and placed in formaldehyde-free Carosafe®. This produces a formalin-preserved specimen that, when dissected, minimizes exposure to formaldehyde.

The primary component of Carosafe<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> is propylene glycol, a common ingredient used in cosmetics and foods. Propylene glycol is on the U.S. Food and Drug Administration’s (FDA’s) list of food additives that are generally recognized as safe. Holding specimens in Carosafe<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> reduces the presence of formaldehyde, thereby diminishing or eliminating unpleasant odor. However, Carosafe<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup>-preserved specimens and their surrounding fluid do contain some residual formaldehyde, a by-product of the initial formalin preservation process. The amount present varies by specimen type.
The dissection should take place in a well-ventilated setting. For a home setting, this may include opening windows and turning on a ceiling fan.
The safe nature of Carosafe® also means that in most localities there are no mandated disposal requirements.

pageData.text: Carolina’s Carosafe<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> causes mild skin irritation if suitable PPE is not worn. Avoid contact with skin and eyes. Respiratory irritation may result if Carosafe<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> specimens are used without adequate ventilation. Carosafe<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> specimens contain substances that are carcinogenic and toxic, and should not be ingested.

pageData.subTitle: Storage of Specimens
pageData.text: If it is necessary to store the specimen between work periods, you may choose to place it in the plastic storage bag with as much of the original solution as possible. Establishing an airtight seal is the best way to retain specimen integrity and prevent drying out of the specimen. First, squeeze as much air out of the specimen bag as possible before securing the opening with a rubber band, tape, or a binder clip. After closing the bag, the specimen can be stored in a larger, airtight box or bag at room temperature.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of these methods of plant propagation will most likely result in genetically diverse offspring?

options.text: planting the seeds from a plant after pollination
planting leaves featuring many small rootlets
grafting a branch from one tree to another
allowing a plant to develop rhizomes
allowing a plant to develop adventitious buds

assestmentData.question: In the sexual life cycle of angiosperms, which of the following structures produces the egg or sperm?
Which of the following describes two gametes from one plant fusing together?
What part of the flower produces the eggs and protects the developing seed, located at the center of the flower?
Which of the following allows the sperm to travel from the stigma, through the style, and to the ovule for egg fertilization?
A botanical fruit, such as a tomato, is which of the following structures of an angiosperm?
Angiosperms that rely on wind as their pollinator have which of the following adaptations?

options.text: Their flowers produce large amounts of pollen.
Their flowers are broad and bowl-shaped.
Their flowers have an intense odor.
Their flowers are bright and showy.
Their flowers only bloom at night.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following items will you need to supply yourself to complete this investigation?
Which of the following describes INAPPROPRIATE use of a scalpel?

options.text: cutting toward your holding hand and fingers
cutting in a downward motion using a steady, even pressure
inspecting your blade for nicks or damage
using a scalpel only for dissection purposes

assestmentData.question: Which of the following safety warnings is associated with BOTH Carolina’s Perfect Solution<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> and the Carosafe<sup class='bodySupscript'>®</sup> preservation fluids used for the specimens in this investigation?

options.text: Avoid contact with skin and eyes.
Dispose of excess solution at a waste management facility.
Wear two layers of gloves as these solutions are corrosive.
Avoid breathing in their toxic fumes.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.

In Activity 1, you will examine and dissect four preserved <button class='glossary-text'>flowers</button> to compare their <button class='glossary-text'>petals</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>stamen</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>pistil</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>styles</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>ovaries</button>.
Read all instructions and obtain all materials.
Clean and sanitize the work area.
Put on a pair of new gloves. Anytime you feel that the gloves are soiled or damaged during the investigation, change them.
Take each <button class='glossary-text'>flower</button> out of the flask using the forceps.
Put each flower on a paper towel.
With a new paper towel, carefully pat the flowers dry. Take care not to damage the floral structures.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Take a photograph of each of the flowers.

Pick up each flower, and examine its exterior. Note the position of the flower, the number of flowers per <button class='glossary-text'>receptacle</button>, and the number per <button class='glossary-text'>peduncle</button>. You may wish to refer to Figures 4–7 to compare the preserved samples to an image of the living flower.

image.altText: Figure 4: Bicolor daylily flowers in orange and yellow

altText: Figure 4: Bicolor daylily flowers in orange and yellow

pageData.text: Carefully remove each <button class='glossary-text'>petal</button> with the scalpel.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Compare the number, position, and size of the petals for each plant. Take a photograph of each flower, and record the data in Data Table 1.
Open the flower, and spread it out carefully on a new piece of paper towel. Make sure not to damage the <button class='glossary-text'>stamen</button> or <button class='glossary-text'>pistil</button>.

When you are dissecting the cucumber flower, you will not be able to complete all the steps, depending on the structures present in your specimen. Cucumber flowers are monoecious, meaning each flower contains only male or female reproductive structures, not both. The cucumber specimen in this kit will have only one set of reproductive structures.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Count the number of stamens, and measure the stamen length. Take a photograph of each flower showing its stamens, and record this data in Data Table 1.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Count the number of pistils, and measure their lengths for each flower. Record this data in Data Table 1. Take a photograph of each flower showing the pistils of each.
Carefully remove the stamen with the scalpel.
Examine the stamen with the magnifying lens.
Examine the <button class='glossary-text'>style</button> with the magnifying lens.
Measure the length of each style, and record it in Data Table 1.
Measure the length of each , and record it in Data Table 1.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Examine the <button class='glossary-text'>stigma</button> with the magnifying lens. Take a photograph of each flower showing their stigmas. Note any differences in the size and width of the stigma. Note the indentation in the center of the stigma. This is the area where the pollen attaches itself.
Select the flower with the largest ovary.
Use a scalpel to remove the pistil from the flower.
Carefully remove the style from the pistil.
Lay the ovary on a new paper towel.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Carefully cut lengthwise with the scalpel through the middle of the ovary to open it up. Take a photograph of the ovary of this flower.
Locate the <button class='glossary-text'>ovules</button> with the magnifying glass.
Examine the style with a magnifying lens. Note the central canal running down from the stigma to the ovary.

text: Place the specimens and their parts in the storage bag(s) and seal tightly. If you are finished working with your specimens, put the bag(s) into an opaque trash bag for disposal in the household garbage.
Dispose of the containers with the preservation fluid, and any other waste from the activity, in the household garbage.
Rinse and carefully air dry the dissection tools, and return the materials to your equipment kit.
Sanitize the workspace with isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant) and paper towels.

Number of petals
and shape of flower

text: When comparing the different flowers, which of the flowers relies on larger insects and birds and which will rely on wind for pollination? Explain your answers.
Cucumber flowers are monoecious, meaning an individual flower will have either male or female structures, but not both. Explain how sexual reproduction occurs in plants with monoecious flowers.

Besides looking at the number of flowers to increase the number of seeds, which other part of the flower is responsible for making more seeds? Compare the data collected from the different flower parts and use your observations in your answer.

pageData.content: Figure 1. Sexual life cycle of flowering plants
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Plant life cycle. Alternation of generations between a diploid sporophyte and a haploid gametophyte.
Figure 2: Labeled diagram of the parts of a flower.
Figure 3: Dogwood flowers illustrating bracts, which superficially resemble flower petals.

pageData.title: Table 1. Flower characteristics and the type of pollinator that will be attracted.

tableData.text: Small with no or small petals
Large funnel shaped with strong foundation

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow of this investigation. Remove and dry the specimen, then examine its exterior. Then, examine the number, position, and size of the petals. Next, spread open the specimen, and count the stamen number and measure the stamen length. Then, count the pistil number and measure the pistil length. Next, remove and examine the stamen. Then, examine the style and measure the style length. Then, examine the stigma. If the specimen has the largest ovary, isolate the ovary and cut it in half lengthwise. This activity is repeated for the four flower specimens in the investigation.
Figure 4: Bicolor daylily flowers in orange and yellow
Figure 5: Red-pink chrysanthemum flowers
Figure 6: Fuchsia honeysuckle flowers
Figure 7: Yellow cucumber flowers

data.title: Anther
data.content: The part of the stamen that contains the pollen

data.title: Asexual reproduction
data.content: The method of reproduction that occurs without recombination of genetic material

data.title: Calyx
data.content: The outer whorl of a flower consisting of multiple sepals

data.title: Composite flower
data.content: A plant that produces a flower head composed of many tiny flowers (florets)

data.title: Embryo
data.content: The part of the seed or bud that contains the earliest stages of growth

data.title: Filament
data.content: The thread-like stalk that supports the anther of a flower

data.title: Flower
data.content: A specialized  structure for sexual reproduction

data.title: Fruit
data.content: The matured ovary of a flowering plant

data.title: Gamete
data.content: A reproductive cell containing only half the genetic material necessary to form a complete organism

data.title: Haploid
data.content: Having a single set of unpaired chromosomes

data.title: Meiosis
data.content: A type of cell division in sexually reproducing organisms that reduces the number of chromosomes in gametes

data.title: Ovary
data.content: The enlarged lower part of the pistil that contains the ovules

data.title: Ovule
data.content: The part of the ovary that will develop into a seed when the egg within is fertilized; contains the female gametophyte of the plant

data.title: Peduncle
data.content: The stalk that bears a flower on a flowering plant

data.title: Petal
data.content: A leaf-like structure, multiples of which are arranged in a circle around the top of the stem within the sepals

data.title: Pistil
data.content: The part of the flower that produces eggs and protects the developing seed

data.title: Pollen grain
data.content: The structure produced in the anther of a flower and which contains the male gametophyte of the plant

data.title: Pollen tube
data.content: The hollow tube that develops from a pollen grain when it is deposited on the stigma of a flower; it penetrates the style and conveys the male gametes to the ovule

data.title: Pollination
data.content: The process of delivering pollen to the stigma

data.title: Receptacle
data.content: The part of the flower stalk to which the floral parts are attached

data.title: Rhizome
data.content: A horizontal underground plant stem capable of asexually producing the shoot and root sytem of a new plant

data.title: Seed
data.content: The structure which, in most plants, protects the embryo; in some plants it also nourishes the embryo

data.title: Self-fertilization
data.content: The process of sexual reproduction in which two gametes from one plant fuse together to form a zygote

data.title: Sepal
data.content: A leaf-like structure, multiples of which encircle the flower stem and enclose the bud

data.title: Sexual reproduction
data.content: A method of reproduction that utilizes recombines two different sets of DNA to produce offspring with genetic makeups different from those of either of the two parents

data.title: Stamen
data.content: The male reproductive part of the flower made up of the filament and anther

data.title: Stigma
data.content: The sticky pad that receives pollen grains at the top of the style of a flower

data.title: Style
data.content: The tube-like structure that connects the stigma and ovary of a flower

data.title: Vegetative reproduction
data.content: A form of asexual reproduction where a plant produces tissue capable of regenerating  all the tissues necessary to form a new plant

data.title: Zygote
data.content: A cell formed by the union of two gametes
